channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Shalit back in Israel after swap
item.description: Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit arrives home after five years' captivity in Gaza, as the first of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners are freed as part of a prisoner exchange.

item.title: Clinton in unannounced Libya trip
item.description: US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is in Libya on an unannounced visit aimed at showing support for the Libyan people and building ties as fierce fighting breaks out in Sirte.

item.title: Ruling 'threatens stem cell work'
item.description: Europe's highest court has ruled that stem cells from human embryos cannot be patented, in a case that could have major implications for medicine.

item.title: Blatter set for Fifa bribes probe U-turn
item.description: Fifa president Sepp Blatter is set to call for the release of court documents which could reveal that top officials at the football body took bribes.

item.title: Malaria deaths fall 20% in decade
item.description: There has been a fall of just over 20% in the number of deaths from malaria worldwide in the past decade, the World Health Organization says.

item.title: Tibet nun 'dies in fire protest'
item.description: A Tibetan nun sets herself on fire near a restive monastery in western China, in the ninth such incident in recent months, reports say.

item.title: Kenya troops 'advance in Somalia'
item.description: Kenyan troops with aerial support continuing their advance into Somalia, as a suspected suicide car bomb kills at least three civilians in Mogadishu.

item.title: Climate 'grave' security threat
item.description: Climate change poses "an immediate, growing and grave threat" to health and security around the world, according to an expert conference in London.

item.title: Goldman Sachs reports $393m loss
item.description: Goldman Sachs reports a $393m quarterly loss, after its trading was hit by the eurozone crisis and wider global woes.

item.title: Ex-warlord backs Liberia leader
item.description: Former rebel leader Prince Johnson, who came third in Liberia's election, says he will back President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf in the second round.

item.title: UK seizes Iranian accused assets
item.description: The UK Treasury says it has frozen the assets of five men suspected of an Iranian plot to assassinate Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States.

item.title: Britain sets Olympic truce record
item.description: Britain sets an early Olympic record by getting all 193 UN member states to sponsor the traditional call for a truce during the London 2012 Games, as the BBC's Barbara Plett reports.

item.title: Branson launches desert spaceport
item.description: Sir Richard Branson has dedicated the launchpad for his space tourism venture in the New Mexico desert - with his usual eye for a photo opportunity.

item.title: IRB to assess Gatland cheat claim
item.description: The International Rugby Board is to review Warren Gatland's claim he considered cheating in Wales' World Cup semi-final defeat by France.

item.title: Sportsday Live - Tuesday 18 October
item.description: Sportsday Live - featuring Warren Gatland's admission he thought about cheating and the build-up to tonight's Champions League games, plus more.

item.title: Relegation idea stupid - Whelan
item.description: Wigan chairman Dave Whelan says he would pull his club out of the Premier League if promotion and relegation were scrapped.

item.title: UK inflation rate rises to 5.2%
item.description: The rate of Consumer Prices Index inflation rose to 5.2% in September from 4.5% the month before, matching the record level set in September 2008.

item.title: Liam Fox 'was warned on Werritty'
item.description: Ex-Defence Secretary Liam Fox ignored warnings about his working relationship with Adam Werritty, an official report is expected to say.

item.title: Facebook riot appeals rejected
item.description: The Court of Appeal has rejected appeals by two men jailed for using Facebook to try to incite disorder during August's riots in England.

item.title: Arrest over four miners' deaths
item.description: A man, believed to be the colliery manager, is arrested in connection with the manslaughter of four miners in the Swansea Valley.

item.title: Soap actor 'drove killer gunman'
item.description: Former Brookside actor Brian Regan was involved in the murder of a man who was shot outside a Liverpool pub, a court is told.

item.title: Mother weeps over Jo Yeates photo
item.description: The mother of landscape architect Jo Yeates cries as a photograph of her daughter's body is shown to the jury at the murder trial of Vincent Tabak.

item.title: McIntyre has Rangers cash frozen
item.description: Former Rangers director Donald McIntyre wins a court order freezing Â£300,000 of the club's assets.

item.title: City gardens design plans on show
item.description: Designs for the controversial plans to transform Union Terrace Gardens in Aberdeen are revealed to the public.

item.title: Liam Adams' appeal bid dismissed
item.description: The brother of Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams is not allowed to appeal his extradition from the Republic of Ireland to answer charges of sexually abusing his daughter.

item.title: Robert Black 'had tape and rags'
item.description: The Jennifer Cardy murder trial hears that searches of Robert Black's van and home uncovered tape, rags and children's clothing.

item.title: Kenyan terror police hold men, 18
item.description: Two 18-year-old men from Cardiff are being questioned by anti-terror police in Kenya after being arrested crossing the border into Somalia.

item.title: Consent plan for child piercings
item.description: Under-16s would be stopped from having their skin pierced without their parents' permission under a Welsh government proposal.

item.title: Iran pours scorn on Saudi 'plot'
item.description: Iran's President Ahmadinejad says US allegations of a plot to assassinate a Saudi envoy are as false as its claims were about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

item.title: N Korea to discuss US war remains
item.description: North Korea and the US hold talks on restarting efforts to recover the remains of US troops killed during the Korean War, after a six-year halt.

item.title: Kidnapped Colombian girl released
item.description: A Colombian girl, Nohora Valentina Munoz, whose kidnapping shocked the nation, has been released, President Juan Manuel Santos says.

item.title: Central America rains toll rises
item.description: The number of people killed by a week of torrential rains in Central America, which triggered floods and landslides, has risen to at least 80, officials say.

item.title: SA court action over Dalai Lama
item.description: South Africa's opposition calls for a judicial review of the government's failure to give the Dalai Lama a visa to attend Archbishop Desmond Tutu's 80th birthday earlier this month.

item.title: Malaysia raids human traffickers
item.description: Malaysian police say they have broken up a ring of human traffickers who forced Ugandan women into prostitution.

item.title: Shares fall on France rating fear
item.description: European shares fall after Moody's warns about France's credit rating and figures show a slowdown in the rate of China's economic growth.

item.title: Botswana air crash kills tourists
item.description: Seven European tourists die in a plane crash in Botswana's Okavango Delta region, air safety officials say.

item.title: 'Renewed deadly clashes in Homs'
item.description: At least 21 people, including civilians and police, are killed in renewed clashes in the Syrian city of Homs, activists say.

item.title: Heavy fighting in Yemeni capital
item.description: Fierce fighting resumes in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, between forces loyal to President Ali Abdullah Saleh and his opponents.

item.title: Taliban 'must disarm for talks'
item.description: Pakistan will hold peace talks with the Taliban only if the militants lay down their weapons first, Interior Minister Rehman Malik says.

item.title: India row over Hindu epic essay
item.description: A row breaks out in the Indian capital over whether Delhi university should teach a controversial essay about the Hindu epic, the Ramayana.

item.title: Bangkok flood threat 'not over'
item.description: Soldiers and civilians reinforce floodwalls in northern Bangkok, after a warning Thailand's worst floods in decades still pose a threat to the capital.

item.title: Strike-hit Papua mine 'producing'
item.description: Operators say production has resumed at the Freeport-McMoran mine in Papua, Indonesia, but at reduced levels amid a blockade and alleged sabotage by striking workers.

item.title: China's economic growth slows
item.description: China's economic expansion slows during the third quarter of the year as government measures to control inflation hurt growth.

item.title: HTC loses Apple patent case in US
item.description: Taiwan's HTC is dealt a big blow as the US International Trade Commission says Apple did not violate its patents.

item.title: Olympus ex-boss takes case to SFO
item.description: Sacked Olympus boss Michael Woodford says he has contacted the UK's Serious Fraud Office about the Japanese firm's accounting practices.

item.title: Warning over web security attack
item.description: A key web security system is no better defended now than when hackers undermined it earlier this year, says security guru.

item.title: Machine vision spots rotten fruit
item.description: Spanish researchers develop a machine that uses artificial vision and UV light to scan through citrus fruits and get rid of rotten ones.

item.title: BlackBerry answers your questions
item.description: The UK boss of BlackBerry answers your questions about the recent service problems.

item.title: Julian Barnes leads Booker race
item.description: Four-time nominee Julian Barnes is favourite to win the Man Booker Prize, while nominees react to accusations from some literary circles that it has become too populist.

item.title: Storm-ravaged festival to return
item.description: The Belgian festival hit by violent storms which killed four music fans and injured more than 70 others will return in 2012.

item.title: Stone Roses to reunite for tour
item.description: Influential Manchester rock band The Stone Roses announce the end of a 15-year split to stage a world tour and record new material.

item.title: Med Bluefin tuna catch 'unabated'
item.description: Bluefin tuna boats in the Mediterranean Sea continue to catch many more fish than they report, a study concludes.

item.title: Weather halts NZ oil ship pumping
item.description: More stormy weather forces another halt to efforts to pump oil off a leaking cargo ship grounded off New Zealand's coast.

item.title: Fish farms may face coastal ban
item.description: Fish farming could be banned in some coastal areas in a bid to protect wild fish stocks, a BBC Scotland investigation reveals.

item.title: Bacterium linked to bowel cancer
item.description: A type of bacterium known to cause dental decay and skin ulcers has been linked to bowel cancer.

item.title: Switch clue to pregnancy problems
item.description: Scientists have identified a "fertility switch" protein which appears to increase infertility if levels are too high and fuel miscarriage if too low.

item.title: Low birthweight 'link to autism'
item.description: Babies born weighing less than 4lb (1.8kg) could be more prone to developing autism than children born at normal weight, a study suggests.

item.title: Central American floods: Eyewitness pictures
item.description: El Salvador resident Eric Lemus spoke to the BBC about the flooding in his country.

item.title: Arab League calls for Syria talks
item.description: The Arab League has called for talks between the government and opposition in Syria to be held within 15 days under its supervision, following months of unrest.

item.title: Searching for the next Google
item.description: Can innovation create the jobs needed to end the era of high unemployment?

item.title: Why would thieves steal a bridge?
item.description: Two Pennsylvania men have been charged with cutting up a steel bridge and selling it for scrap. Why is the US in the grip of a destructive rash of metal thefts?

item.title: Gilad Shalit: A 1,000-to-one asymmetry
item.description: A single Israeli soldier appears to equate to a 1,000 Palestinian prisoners. How can this be?

item.title: VIDEO: The evolution of driverless pods
item.description: Could personal rapid transit, similar to the driverless pods moving people around Heathrow airport in London, provide a future solution for cities?

item.title: VIDEO: Dust storm darkens skies in Texas town
item.description: A dust storm made a town in Texas look more like Mars on Monday, as winds of up to 70 miles an hour churned up a cloud of red dust almost 1.5 miles (2.4km) high.

item.title: VIDEO: Abbas on Palestinian prisoners' release
item.description: Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas greeted the prisoners before speaking in front of a huge crowd in Ramallah, where he assured the released prisoners their struggle would pay off.

item.title: VIDEO: Netanyahu: Deal cost high price
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says meeting freed soldier Gilad Shalit and returning him to his family was a "very exciting moment".

item.title: VIDEO: Court steps into L'Oreal heiress row
item.description: Billionaire L'Oreal heiress Liliane Bettencourt, 88, is to be placed under her family's guardianship over concerns about her mental health.

item.title: AUDIO: Polynesia denies cannibalism claim
item.description: The deputy mayor of Nuku Hiva told Radio 5 live that charred remains found on the island were not necessarily a sign of cannibalism.

item.title: VIDEO: Image change for nuclear power in Japan
item.description: The nuclear industry in Japan is trying to allay fears about the safety of nuclear energy following the tsunami and subsequent meltdown at Fukushima nuclear plant.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Sky high' electrician fixes cable
item.description: A specialist electrician has carried out repairs on an ultra-high voltage power line in eastern China.

item.title: Spain's stolen babies
item.description: The 'dead' children who lived - Spain begins to learn the truth

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 October 2011
item.description: A selection of striking images from around the world

item.title: Can anyone run a marathon at 100?
item.description: How can anyone run a marathon at 100?

item.title: Motorsport stunned by Wheldon tragedy
item.description: World of motorsport stunned by Wheldon tragedy

item.title: Pirate Parties: From digital rights to political power
item.description: The meteoric rise of a new political force

item.title: Why are more people changing their name?
item.description: Why are increasing numbers altering their name?

item.title: India's internet surfing and shopping boom
item.description: More Indians are discovering the delights of shopping on the web
